page.title: 07OSBASTON HOLLOW
page.content: {The Gate Public House}and{Gnarley {Cottage}were built about 200 years ago, the latter probably providing stabling for the Inn. The Gate probably takes its name from the old Toll Gate at the top of the hill. Gnarley Cottage was used (1912) as a wheelwrights, carpenters and coopers. The local road was previously known as Brick Kiln Close, which suggest there was probably a kiln there at some time in the past. The{Gnarleys refer to the spinney behind the allotments. In the 19th century the land belonged to the Poyser family and later Elizabeth Freeman until 1934. One inhabitant still remembers the cottages at the beginning of the century having water pumps, wells, two earth closets between six houses, a coal house and a pigsty each. Waste water ran away in an open channel.
